value.text: Minji and I first met at a Korean language school in the Michigan suburbs. It was the early 2000s, and every Saturday morning our parents, drawn to Detroit by the promise of the auto industry, dropped us off to learn Korean language and culture. We were the same age, and in a classroom full of kids wearing sparkly Limited Too tops or oversized Pokémon and Dragon Ball Z T-shirts, we found each other through K-pop.
value.speaker: eunice

value.text: That shared obsession quickly turned into regular playdates at her house, where we’d sit cross-legged in the living room and play BoA’s “No. 1” on a silver CD player. Later, when YouTube arrived, we’d crowd around her family desktop and watch the music videos, our eyes glued to the screen. We watched her on repeat – studying the way she moved, the precision of her choreography, and her cathartic vocals. We’d rewind the same eight-count over and over, trying to get it right. Sometimes we did. Mostly, we laughed, got it wrong, and hit play again.
value.speaker: minji
